content.title: Myocardial Infarction Definition
content.summary: Acute necrosis of myocardial tissue due to prolonged ischemia, typically from coronary artery occlusion
key_points: Type 3 MI: Sudden cardiac death with ischemic symptoms
Troponin elevation required with rise/fall pattern
Fourth Universal Definition is current standard

statement.text: Myocardial infarction (MI) is irreversible myocardial cell death due to prolonged ischemia, defined by detection of elevated cardiac biomarkers (preferably troponin) with rise and/or fall pattern plus at least one of: symptoms of acute myocardial ischemia, new ischemic ECG changes, development of pathological Q waves, imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or regional wall motion abnormality in a pattern consistent with ischemic etiology.
statement.formal: MI = Troponin rise/fall + (Symptoms OR ECG changes OR Q waves OR Imaging evidence of myocardial damage)

explanation.intuition: A heart attack occurs when blood flow to part of the heart muscle is blocked long enough to cause irreversible cell death. The critical concept is 'time is muscle' - every minute of ischemia causes more myocardial damage. The heart muscle is exquisitely sensitive to oxygen deprivation because it cannot function anaerobically for long.
explanation.key_insight: The Fourth Universal Definition distinguishes 5 types of MI based on mechanism: atherothrombotic (Type 1) vs supply-demand mismatch (Type 2) have different treatments. Type 1 requires revascularization; Type 2 requires treating the underlying cause (e.g., anemia, tachyarrhythmia).
explanation.technical_details: Troponin must show a rise and/or fall pattern to distinguish acute MI from chronic troponin elevation (e.g., CKD, heart failure). The 99th percentile upper reference limit (URL) is the decision level. High-sensitivity troponin (hs-cTn) allows earlier detection (within 1-3 hours vs 6-12 hours for conventional troponin).

definitions_glossary.myocardial_infarction: Irreversible death of heart muscle cells (cardiomyocytes) due to prolonged ischemia
definitions_glossary.troponin: Cardiac-specific regulatory protein (troponin I or T) released into bloodstream when myocardial cells die
definitions_glossary.ischemia: Insufficient blood supply to tissue resulting in oxygen deprivation
definitions_glossary.atherothrombosis: Thrombus formation on a ruptured or eroded atherosclerotic plaque
definitions_glossary.plaque_rupture: Disruption of fibrous cap covering atherosclerotic plaque, exposing thrombogenic lipid core
definitions_glossary.supply_demand_mismatch: Imbalance between myocardial oxygen delivery and consumption without acute coronary thrombosis
definitions_glossary.pathological_Q_waves: Deep Q waves (>1mm) indicating transmural myocardial necrosis
definitions_glossary.regional_wall_motion_abnormality: Segment of ventricular wall with reduced or absent contraction
definitions_glossary.99th_percentile_URL: Upper reference limit of troponin in healthy population, threshold for MI diagnosis
definitions_glossary.high_sensitivity_troponin: Assay capable of detecting troponin at very low concentrations in healthy individuals
definitions_glossary.cardiomyocyte: Individual heart muscle cell responsible for myocardial contraction
definitions_glossary.transmural_infarction: Full-thickness myocardial necrosis extending from endocardium to epicardium
definitions_glossary.subendocardial_infarction: Partial-thickness necrosis limited to inner myocardial layers

pathophysiology.mechanism: Prolonged myocardial ischemia (typically >20-30 minutes) causes ATP depletion, calcium overload, membrane rupture, and cell death. Necrosis begins in subendocardium (most vulnerable to ischemia) and extends transmurally as ischemia duration increases ('wavefront phenomenon').
cellular_events: 0-20 min: Reversible ischemic injury (ATP depletion, anaerobic glycolysis)
20-60 min: Irreversible injury begins, membrane integrity loss
3-6 hours: Troponin release detectable in blood
pathophysiology.wavefront_phenomenon: Necrosis starts at subendocardium and progresses transmurally over time; early reperfusion can salvage epicardial myocardium

fourth_universal_definition.required: Rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin with at least one value above 99th percentile URL
plus_one_of: Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium
Intracoronary thrombus identified on angiography or autopsy

type_classification.type_1: Atherothrombotic CAD with plaque rupture, erosion, or dissection
type_classification.type_2: Oxygen supply-demand mismatch without acute coronary thrombosis
type_classification.type_3: MI resulting in death when biomarkers unavailable

reperfusion_therapy.PCI: Primary PCI preferred for STEMI if door-to-balloon <90 min
reperfusion_therapy.fibrinolysis: Alternative for STEMI if PCI not available within 120 min
reperfusion_therapy.CABG: For left main disease, multivessel CAD, or failed PCI

definition.@value: Irreversible myocardial cell death due to prolonged ischemia, diagnosed by elevated cardiac biomarkers with rise/fall pattern plus clinical evidence of myocardial ischemia

skos.scopeNote: Fourth Universal Definition (2018) is current standard; includes Type 1-5 classification
skos.example: A 55-year-old male with crushing chest pain, diaphoresis, ST-elevation in leads V1-V4, and troponin I elevated to 5.2 ng/mL with serial rise

medicalCode.description: ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction of anterior wall

learning_objectives: Define myocardial infarction using the Fourth Universal Definition criteria
Classify MI into Types 1-5 based on underlying mechanism
Interpret troponin results including rise/fall pattern significance
Differentiate Type 1 vs Type 2 MI for treatment decisions
Describe the wavefront phenomenon of myocardial necrosis
clinical_pearls: Type 2 MI treatment focuses on underlying cause, not revascularization
Troponin rise/fall pattern distinguishes acute MI from chronic elevation (CKD, CHF)
hs-cTnI can detect MI within 1-3 hours vs 6-12 hours for conventional troponin
Door-to-balloon time <90 min is critical for STEMI outcomes
Subendocardium dies first - early reperfusion saves epicardial muscle

board_yield.usmle_step1: High - pathophysiology of ischemic injury, troponin mechanism
board_yield.usmle_step2: Very High - MI diagnosis, classification, treatment algorithm
board_yield.usmle_step3: High - Type 1 vs Type 2 distinction, secondary prevention
board_yield.internal_medicine_boards: Very High - acute management, complications, prognosis

common_misconceptions: All elevated troponins indicate MI (false - need rise/fall pattern + clinical context)
Type 2 MI requires coronary intervention (false - treat underlying cause)
Normal ECG excludes MI (false - posterior MI, early MI may have normal ECG)

skos:related.skos:note: MI is a subset of ACS
Troponin is central to MI diagnosis
